Are we talking about military drones (like Predator and Reaper) or consumer drones? Nearly all current consumer drones are under direct radio/wifi/etc control (which is to say, they frequently do on-board stabilization and pathkeeping, but their instructions come from the ground) and in my experience, the way they are linked up with their control system rarely even reaches the bluetooth pairing level of security. A favorite project is SkyJack - autonomous drone hacking which is designed specifically to deal with the AR Drone 2.0. Building on top of that (once you've taken control) is another project - Maldrone the First Backdoor for drones. SkyJack disrupts the drone's connection to ground control and then steps in when the drone searches for connection again, while Maldrone insures that you can retain control of the drone even after hardware resets. Now if we're talking about military drones, you'd think those would be super-hardened and unhackable... unless you know that there's no such thing. Wondering how to hack a military drone? It's all on Google - most of that appears to deal with exploiting weaknesses in GPS which almost certainly has wider applications than just drone hacking.

What really matters is the scale, cost (time and resource) and payoff of hacking, the exact same things matter to data exfiltration and identity theft. If your precious hours are spent to crack 1 drone then all you get is a flying good-for-nothing without warranty.

Drones, after all, are essentially flying computers. As such, they're susceptible to the same type of hacks as a laptop or smartphone. Drone hacking technology can be used to either swipe the data that the machines collect or even take over their physical control [sources: de Looper, Sternstein, Moskovitch].
